div.p:
Having reached this the
furthest inland station of the Portuguese
in Eastern Africa on the 2d CurrtCurrent - I have
much pleasure in remembering the
friends I left behind me some years ago -
I could give you no more than a
wretched scrawl from Sekeletu's for
my Arab friend who was taking some
notes to Angola was in a desperate hurry
to be off - I got the letter you sent the year
before that but you would see that had
you come yourselves we should not
have had the pleasure of meeting. Africa
is a very wide country, one can go
no where quickly and while at LoandaLuanda
I was long delayed by a severe attack
of disease. In coming Eastward we
followed in a general way the course
of the ZambesiZambezi. It flows Eastwards
from Sesheke to the falls then having
passed that wonderful spot, it winds
away N.N.E.North Northeast till it reaches the Lat.Latitude
15° 37' South. The falls are in 17° 57' S.South
There passing Eastward it turns down
again to the South East to QuilimaneQuelimane
The falls are not like other waterfalls - This
is simply an enourmous rent made in
the hard basaltic rock of the bottom or bed
from bank to bank - and prolonged from
the left bank away through thirty or forty
miles of hills - The rent is about 100 feet
deep and from 60 to 80 feet apart at the
lips. Into this the river of a thousand
yards precipitates itself and being compressed
at the bottom into fifteen or twenty, the
pressure is so great as to cause large
columns of vapour to rush up 300
or 400 feet high - these at that height lose
their steam colours become dark and descend
in a constant shower of the condensed
water. When the river has got through
its place of confinement it flows broad
and placid again but there are one
or two little rocky rapids below - Here
it is 500 fathoms or 1000 yards and
it is often much broader - It however
becomes spread out among numerous
branches among the deltas of QuilimaneQuelimane
and sailors passing along dontdon't percieveperceive
its size except by finding fresh water
out 20 miles from the land. It is
never fordable but becomes lower
in summer than it is now - the land
is very fertile and the inhabitants raise
immense quantities of grain. they
had been fighting with the Portuguese before
we came and burned all their five villas
Tete is in ruins - SennaSena DoDitto QuilimaneQuelimane
not much better - there being real Caffres
there who are called Landeens. SennaSena
and QuilimaneQuelimaneQuelimane are very deadly but
Tete is better and a part higher up the
river is still more salubrious - We
through the sickly districts
ne of the year if we can
without the children. Get more when
we are there if we can - ! That's what
Mr Ashton would call moral courage
Aun.Ann. is it not - ? I am waiting here
till the beginning of April partly to rest
myself and partly to allow the healthy
season to set in at QuilimaneQuelimane before
breathing its febrile vapours I was
pretty well knocked up, for the oxen all
died of Tsetse and then I had to march
on foot - this is very well for those
who are fond of pedestrianism or
need their obesity reduced like Mamary -
but for me who had become as lean
as a lath the only good I saw in the
constant trudging was it gave an honest
fellow a pretty good idea of the treadmill,
I am very well now but drank enormous
quantities of water after my arrival
as if I had exchanged my own teetotal
inner man for the derms of some
drunkard. The Portuguese have been
remarkably kind both here and in Angola
and I am very thankful to God for
having enabled me to perform all I
proposed and preserved my life
where so many have fallen. Hope
your children are better - May God bless
you abundantly Ever yours Affectionately
David Livingstone

Left QuilimaneQuelimane 12 July E
at Mauritius 12 August
DL.David Livingstone

Now that your mission has fraternized
with the Boer Kirk, are you permitted
to go where you like? And preach where
you like? Or what benefit have you
derived from the alliance? I suppose
